articles.headline: New to Being Dry, the South Struggles to Adapt
articles.snippet: The response to the worst drought on record in the Southeast has unfolded in ultra-slow motion.
articles.abstract: The response to the worst drought on record in the Southeast has unfolded in ultra-slow motion.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Oct. 22  For more than five months, the lake that provides drinking water to almost five million people here has been draining away in a withering drought. Sandy beaches have expanded into flats of orange mud. Tree stumps not seen in half a century have resurfaced. Scientists have warned of impending disaster.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Brenda Goodman

articles.headline: Bill Allowing Mortgage Lawsuits Expected to Stir Fierce Opposition
articles.snippet: The bill is part of a measure aimed at curbing what some consumer advocates say are deceptive lending practices aimed at people with low incomes or poor credit histories.
articles.abstract: The bill is part of a measure aimed at curbing what some consumer advocates say are deceptive lending practices aimed at people with low incomes or poor credit histories.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 — House Democrats introduced legislation on Monday that would for the first time let homeowners sue Wall Street firms for relief from mortgages that the borrowers never had a realistic chance of repaying.

articles.headline: In Iraq, Conflict Simmers on a 2nd Kurdish Front
articles.snippet: Kurdish guerrillas are ambushing Iranian forces in battles chillingly similar to raids into Turkey in northern Iraq.
articles.abstract: Kurdish guerrillas are ambushing Iranian forces in battles chillingly similar to raids into Turkey in northern Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 22  Deadly raids into Turkey by Kurdish militants holed up in northern Iraq are the focus of urgent diplomacy, with Turkey threatening invasion of Iraq and the United States begging for restraint while expressing solidarity with Turkish anger.

articles.headline: Porsche Seen Likely to Realize VW Merger
articles.snippet: The European Court of Justice is expected to strike down the so-called Volkswagen Law, created by Germany’s government to protect the automaker from an unwanted takeover.
articles.abstract: The European Court of Justice is expected to strike down the so-called Volkswagen Law, created by Germany’s government to protect the automaker from an unwanted takeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Oct. 22 — A 47-year-old German law is the only roadblock that stands between Porsche and its long-sought goal of taking over Volkswagen. On Tuesday, the law is likely to be swept away.

articles.headline: Microsoft Is Yielding in European Antitrust Fight
articles.snippet: European regulators hailed the deal as a breakthrough that should create more competition, especially for server software that powers corporate data centers and the Internet.
articles.abstract: European regulators hailed the deal as a breakthrough that should create more competition, especially for server software that powers corporate data centers and the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft has given up its nine-year fight against antitrust regulators in Europe, saying yesterday that it would not challenge a court judgment from last month and would share technical information with rivals on terms the software giant had long resisted.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Kevin J. O'Brien

articles.headline: Many Red Flags Preceded a Recall of Hamburger
articles.snippet: Questions have been raised about whether the meat industry has been given too much leeway to police itself.
articles.abstract: Questions have been raised about whether the meat industry has been given too much leeway to police itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELIZABETH, N.J. — Over the summer, as Americans fired up their grills, the Topps Meat factory here scrambled to produce thousands of frozen hamburger patties for Wal-Mart and other customers, putting intense pressure on workers.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Ailing Firm Gets Tonic From China
articles.snippet: Although Bear Stearns investors want to see the firm increase its international exposure, there is uncertainty as to whether the Citic deal will contribute to earnings.
articles.abstract: Although Bear Stearns investors want to see the firm increase its international exposure, there is uncertainty as to whether the Citic deal will contribute to earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: When James E. Cayne, 73, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, flew to Beijing over the Labor Day weekend to discuss a partnership with Citic Securities, China’s largest investment bank, the two firm’s fortunes were diverging.

articles.headline: For Love and a Little Money
articles.snippet: Some retirees have found that being paid something for doing volunteer work can be good for both the organization and for themselves.
articles.abstract: Some retirees have found that being paid something for doing volunteer work can be good for both the organization and for themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: BY the time Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr. retired from Cravath, Swain & Moore in 2002, he was financially set. He was already an author, he already had a distinguished track record in public service and philanthropy and, of course, he was the great-grandson of a toy magnate.

articles.headline: Privacy Lost: These Phones Can Find You
articles.snippet: If G.P.S. made it harder to get lost, new cellphone services that track whereabouts are now making it harder to hide.
articles.abstract: If G.P.S. made it harder to get lost, new cellphone services that track whereabouts are now making it harder to hide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two new questions arise, courtesy of the latest advancement in cellphone technology: Do you want your friends, family, or colleagues to know where you are at any given time? And do you want to know where they are?

articles.headline: U.S. Prosecution of Muslim Group Ends in Mistrial
articles.snippet: A federal jury failed to convict any of the former leaders of a Muslim charity charged with financing Middle Eastern terrorists.
articles.abstract: A federal jury failed to convict any of the former leaders of a Muslim charity charged with financing Middle Eastern terrorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS, Oct. 22  A federal judge declared a mistrial on Monday in what was widely seen as the government’s flagship terrorism-financing case after prosecutors failed to persuade a jury to convict five leaders of a Muslim charity on any of the charges, or even to reach a verdict on many of the 197 counts.
